items.title: Canada's unemployment rate edges down to 6.9% in October
items.summary_auto: The Canadian economy added 67,000 jobs in October and the unemployment rate ticked down to 6.9 per cent, Statistics Canada said on Friday.

items.title: Trump administration fights court ruling to pay food assistance to 42 million amid shutdown
items.summary_auto: A federal judge has ordered U.S. President Donald Trump's administration to fully fund this month's food aid for 42 million low-income Americans by Friday, blocking its plan to only provide reduced benefits during the record-long government shutdown.

items.title: For the first time, Yukon's Legislative Assembly will have more women than men
items.summary_auto: Eleven women and one non-binary MLA were elected in this week’s vote — making up 57 per cent of the legislature. It's the first time in Yukon history that men won't make up the majority of the territory's Legislative Assembly.

items.title: Members of Canadian Sudanese community feel abandoned after violence escalates in Sudan
items.summary_auto: Members of Toronto’s Sudanese community say they feel abandoned by the Canadian government amid escalating violence in Sudan.

items.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi brings rain and destruction to Vietnam as death toll nears 190 in Philippines
items.summary_auto: At least five people died in Vietnam after Typhoon Kalmaegi pummelled coastal regions with destructive winds and heavy rain, officials said on Friday, following the storm's deadly passage through the Philippines where it killed at least 188 people.

items.title: Sudanese fighters accused of massacres use Canadian-made rifles
items.summary_auto: The Rapid Support Forces in Sudan, accused of civilian massacres, have posted numerous images posing with rifles bearing the logo of a small B.C. manufacturer called Sterling Cross Defense Systems. Experts say Canada needs to 'do better' to allow for public tracking of arms sales.

items.title: Worried about being fingerprinted? What snowbirds need to know about U.S. registration requirement
items.summary_auto: As snowbirds flock to the border to escape the Canadian winter, many are encountering confusion as they try to comply with new U.S. registration requirements. Here's what we know about the new rules.

items.title: What's going on with the Canada Post strikes?
items.summary_auto: More than a month into rotating Canada Post strikes, workers and the businesses that use the national postal service are grappling with uncertainty.

items.title: Ottawa and Alberta in formal talks to reset relationship after years of acrimony
items.summary_auto: The Alberta and federal governments are in negotiations to sign a major accord that could reset a relationship that had turned toxic for a decade.

items.title: Hamilton residents request Ontario investigate ArcelorMittal Dofasco for releasing emissions far above limits
items.summary_auto: With ArcelorMittal Dofasco stalling on its green steel plans and releasing emissions above Ontario’s air-quality regulations, Hamilton resident Jochen Bezner says Canada’s largest steelmaker needs to be held accountable.

items.title: A Blue Jays return to the World Series next year won't be easy, but fans have hope
items.summary_auto: It was a tough Game 7 loss on Saturday, and Blue Jays fans were still licking their World Series wounds this week when Toronto pitcher Shane Bieber exercised his player option, forgoing free agency to stay with the club. Just like that, fans, analysts — and even Blue Jays executives — were talking about the possibility that the team could be back on baseball's biggest stage next year.

items.title: Buying a new car? Hidden cameras show some Ontario dealerships adding extra charges and features
items.summary_auto: Marketplace visited 15 car dealerships in the Greater Toronto Area with hidden cameras rolling, posing as customers to see if dealerships honour the price in their ads. We found out some car dealerships add extra charges or features.

items.title: Low prices are hurting the oil sector, but Canada has a few advantages
items.summary_auto: Canadian oil producers are grappling with low commodity prices, but analysts say the sector is buoyed by certain advantages unique to this side of the border.

items.title: By the numbers: Here's what needs to happen in a budget vote to avoid an election
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s government was elected just a few seats shy of a majority, meaning the Liberals will need the cooperation of one of the opposition parties to pass its budget.

items.title: Hockey Canada unveils jerseys for Olympic and Paralympic Games in Italy
items.summary_auto: Hockey Canada unveiled the Olympic hockey jerseys on Thursday for the men’s, women’s and Para teams that will compete at the Milan-Cortina Games.

items.title: #TheMoment Heather Hiscox hosted her final CBC Morning Live
items.summary_auto: Heather Hiscox says goodbye to viewers across Canada as she hosts CBC Morning Live for the final time after 20 years.

items.title: Shots ring out at Universal Ostrich farm in Edgewood, B.C.
items.summary_auto: It happened the same day the Supreme Court of Canada declined to hear an appeal to save the flock at Universal Ostrich from a cull ordered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA).

items.title: Tepid reaction in Mexico to groping of president shows country has ‘normalized gender violence’: expert
items.summary_auto: The tepid and partisan domestic reaction to the apparent sexual assault Tuesday of Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum reveals how normalized gender violence has become in the country, according to experts.

items.title: Vince Gilligan's Pluribus is as great as you guessed it would be. It's also just as surreal
items.summary_auto: Pluribus is a show about change — an insidiously joyful change that (without spoiling the goods) will eventually come for our main character, Carol, too. That is, unless she can figure out a way to undo what’s been wrought on the planet.

items.title: Communities shut water intake from B.C. lake after fuel spill reaches 80,000 litres
items.summary_auto: A local official says small communities on Kamloops Lake in British Columbia have been shutting down their intakes from the waterway after it was revealed that more than 80,000 litres of aviation fuel spilled on its shores in a train derailment last weekend.

items.title: U.S. Senate Republicans veto legislation to limit Trump's ability to attack Venezuela
items.summary_auto: Senate Republicans voted to reject legislation Thursday that would have put a check on U.S. President Donald Trump's ability to launch an attack against Venezuela, as Democrats pressed Congress to take a stronger role in Trump's high-stakes campaign against Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.

items.title: How the son of Russian spies paved the legal path for B.C. ostrich cull
items.summary_auto: In his battle for Canadian citizenship, Alexander Vavilov got an opportunity denied to the owners of B.C. 's Universal Ostrich Farms — a chance to argue his case before Canada's top court. In the process, the son of Russian spies set a legal standard for decision-making "reasonableness" that would doom the B.C. birds six years later.

items.title: U.S. deal could cut costs for popular weight-loss drugs. What’s that mean for Canada?
items.summary_auto: A new deal with major drugmakers, unveiled by U.S. President Donald Trump on Thursday, aims to expand coverage and cut prices for popular weight-loss drugs south of the border. So how much could Trump’s announcement really cut costs? And will Canadians also benefit?

items.title: Musk could become world's 1st trillionaire as Tesla shareholders approve giant pay package
items.summary_auto: Elon Musk won a shareholder vote on Thursday that would give the Tesla CEO stock worth $1 trillion if he hits certain performance targets over the next decade, handing him a chance to become history's first trillionaire.

items.title: Teachers' union taking Alberta government to court over notwithstanding clause
items.summary_auto: The Alberta Teachers’ Association has filed a constitutional challenge of a provincial government law that forced educators across the province back to work and imposed a new contract.

items.title: Alberta RCMP officers won't be charged in fatal shooting of 15-year-old boy: police watchdog
items.summary_auto: An Alberta Serious Response Incident Team investigation says the officers shot at the teenager up to 17 times as he came toward them in a field, holding his arm up in a backpack so that it appeared he was pointing a gun.

items.title: 'We miss you': Kalispell, Mont., launches campaign to woo back Canadian visitors
items.summary_auto: One of Montana's main travel destinations is reaching out to Canadians, offering deals, discounts and specials in an effort to lure them back for a visit. Discover Kalispell, a tourism marketing and management organization for the city in northwest Montana, has unveiled its Kalispell Canadian Welcome Pass.

items.title: Man who threw sandwich at U.S. federal agent found not guilty of assault
items.summary_auto: The man who threw a sandwich and became symbol of resistance to U.S. President Donald Trump's D.C. law enforcement surge has been found not guilty of assault.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Scenes from Prince Harry's visit in Toronto
items.summary_auto: Prince Harry, who served in Afghanistan as a member of the British military, is attending several events in Toronto commemorating veterans ahead of Remembrance Day.
